comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: At the NE corner of Bent and Phillip Streets, Sydney; demolished in 1961 to make way for the State Office Block. More here - www.heritage.nsw.gov.au/10_subnav_08_04_04.htm

comment._content: Thanks for the info, have added a geotag to the image.

comment._content: Hi, I'm an admin for a group called Sydney's older buildings and structures. , and we'd love to have this added to the group!

comment.author: 58761057@N07
comment._content: can i use in the public to being the source?

comment.author: 27331537@N06
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/58761057@N07] From our Flickr profile: You can use our images for research and study purposes. We are also happy for you to use our photos on your blog or website - all we ask is that you cite (and link to) them using the Digital ID number that is listed in the image description. This ensures visitors can get back to the original source. We'd love to see any State Records items you feature on your blog so please email us and include a link to your post. If you wish to reproduce our images for other purposes please contact us. High res versions can also be purchased via Photo Investigator.

comment.author: 51979177@N02
comment._content: Just for interest, a brief historical article on the Government Printing Office appeared in the Sydney Mail on 28/12/1910, p. 36...this issue isn't available via Google News Archive...but it is on microfilm...the article includes a sketch of the Printing Office as it was in 1848, a photo from 1874 (same as this SLNSW pic - acms.sl.nsw.gov.au/item/itemDetailPaged.aspx?itemID=412637), and a pic of the building as it was in 1910 (my microfilm photocopy is so poor I can't tell whether the SM pic of the 1910 building is the same as this SRNSW pic, but it's very similar). The article also gives info on the dates of various additions...an extension(1855)...extension and basement (1869)...the wing facing Bent St (1875)...the 5 story block facing Phillip St (1881-1882)...two additional stories and mansard roof (1895). I gather that the author of the article (W.G.M. Foote) might have been a civil engineer...they appear to have known their stuff.
